title: [K-12] Utilizing Semiotic Tools in Scientific Argumentation Classes: Instructional Design for Critical Discussion Models Based on Experimental Data

context.prior_knowledge: Basic argumentation structures, science content knowledge, and understanding of experimental design/measurement methods. Familiarity with scientific inquiry processes and variable control concepts
context.additional_context: A course focusing on enhancing science pre-service teachers' ability to design argumentation lessons using experimental data in BYOD environments. Integrates scientific inquiry processes with evidence analysis, aiming for lesson designs based on scientific methodologies (observation-measurement-analysis-conclusion).

learning_goals: In science argumentation classes, learners systematically analyze experimental variables using semiotic tools (symbols, diagrams) and design discussions based on the scientific inquiry process.

Through role assignments (pro/con/judge) in a 5-stage argumentation cycle (preparation-claim-refutation-evaluation-reflection), learners strengthen hypothesis verification and variable control skills and derive evidence-based conclusions.

Learners create argumentation activities based on mobile science experiment outputs, complete project-based assessments by analyzing measurement errors in peer feedback, and perform evidence-based improvements.
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
